columns.text:
In this exercise, our task is to calculate the current price of two bonds.

Next, we look at how bond prices evolve as the maturity period gets shorter.

Let's get started!

Let's start by explaining what the bond price is and how it's calculated. Bond price is the present discounted value of future cash returns generated by a bond. In other words, it can be described as the sum of the present values of all future coupon payments plus the present value of the face value at maturity: $$\text{Bond Price} = \text{Future Coupon Payments} + \text{Par value at maturity}

Recall that we can calculate the  present value of the future coupon payments as follows:

$$\text{Future Coupon Payments} = C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) \tag{1}$$

Where:

C - Coupon Payment

t - The number of compounding periods

YTM - Yield To Maturity

The current value of face value at maturity may be calculated as follows:

$$\text{Par Value At Maturity} = \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \tag{2}$$

Where:

FV - Face Value

YTM - Yield to maturity
 
t - The number of compounding periods

We can now input Eq. (1) and Eq. (2) in the original equation to calculate the bond price : $$\text{Bond Price} = C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t}$$ This equation makes it possible to calculate the price of the X and Y bonds for the given parameters.

Let's first calculate the current bond price for bond X. We are given the following information on bond X: 1. The face value is assumed at $1,000 2. The annual coupon rate is 8.5%. The semiannual coupon rate is calculated by dividing the annual rate by 2 - the semiannual coupon rate is thus 4.25% 3. Considering that the time to maturity is 13 years, the number of compounding periods will be 26. This is because the bond pays out the coupons semiannually. 4. The annual yield to maturity is 7%. Divide 7% by 2 to get the semiannual yield to maturity of 3.5% By substituting the given values into the formula, we get: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ X} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] &= (\$1,000 \times0.0425) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.035)^{26}}}{0.035}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.035)^{26}} \\[15pt] &= \$717.839875 + \$408.83767 \\[15pt] &= \$1,126.6775 \end{aligned}$$

Now we repeat the last step, but this time for bond Y. We are given the following information on bond Y: 1. The face value is assumed at $1,000 2. The annual coupon rate is 7%. The semiannual coupon rate is thus 3.5%. 3. Considering that the time to maturity is 13 years, the number of compounding periods will be 26. 4. The annual yield to maturity is 8.5%. Hence, the semiannual yield to maturity of 4.25% By substituting the given values into the formula we get the following bond price for bond Y: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ Y} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] &= (\$1,000 \times0.035) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{26}}}{0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{26}} \\[15pt] &= \$544.46692 + \$338.86159 \\[15pt] &= \$883.32851 \end{aligned}$$ How does the bond price change if the maturity period gets shorter?

We mentioned before that the initial maturity period is 13 years. One year from now, the maturity period will be 12 years (13-1). This means that the number of compounding periods will decrease as well. If the maturity period is 12 years, the number of compounding periods will be 24. Given that the rest of the parameters don't change, the bond price for bond X will be: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ X} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] &= (\$1,000 \times0.0425) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.035)^{24}}}{0.035}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.035)^{24}} \\[15pt] &= \$682.48062 + \$437.95713 \\[15pt] &= \$1,120.43775 \end{aligned}$$

Similarily, the bond price for bond Y one year from now will be: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ Y } &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] &= (\$1,000 \times0.035) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{24}}}{0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{24}} \\[15pt] &= \$520.242255 + \$368.27689 \\[15pt] &= \$888.519 \end{aligned}$$ How did the bond price change for the discount bond X? Did it increase or decrease? What about the premium bond Y?

Three years from now, the maturity period will be ten years for both bonds. Hence, the number of compounding periods will also decrease to 20. Given those changes, the bond price for bond X will be: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ X} &= (\$1,000 \times0.0425) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.035)^{20}}}{0.035}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.035)^{20}} \\[15pt] &= \$604.02714 + \$502.56588 \\[15pt] &= \$1,106.59302 \end{aligned}$$ And for bond Y: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ Y } &= (\$1,000 \times0.035) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{20}}} {0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{20}} \\[15pt] &= \$465.3028 + \$434.98945 \\[15pt] &= \$900.29225 \end{aligned}$$

Eight years from now, the maturity period will be five years for both bonds. Hence, the number of compounding periods will further decrease to 10. Given those changes, the bond price for bond X will be: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ X} &= (\$1,000 \times0.0425) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.035)^{10}}}{0.035}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.035)^{10}} \\[15pt] &= \$353.45572 + \$708.91881 \\[15pt] &= \$1,062.37453 \end{aligned}$$ And for bond Y: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ Y } &= (\$1,000 \times0.035) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{10}}} {0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{10}} \\[15pt] &= \$280.38104 + \$659.5373 \\[15pt] &= \$939.91834 \end{aligned}$$

Twelve years from now, there will be only one year left until both bonds mature. The number of compounding periods will decrease to 2. Given the further decrease in the number of compounding periods, the bond price for bond X will be: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ X} &= (\$1,000 \times0.0425) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.035)^{2}}}{0.035}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.035)^{2}} \\[15pt] &= \$80.737 + \$933.5107 \\[15pt] &= \$1,014.2477 \end{aligned}$$ And for bond Y: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ Y } &= (\$1,000 \times0.035) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{2}}} {0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{2}} \\[15pt] &= \$65.77759 + \$920.1272 \\[15pt] &= \$985.90479 \end{aligned}$$ What happens with the bond price when the maturity period is reached?

Thirteen years from now, the bonds will reach maturity period. When the bond reaches maturity, there will be no more coupon payments, and the bond issuer will repay the owner the face value. As a result, the bond's price will be equal to the face value of the bond. So, both bonds X and Y will have a bond price of $1,000.

Finally, let's draw a graph of how the price changes as the bonds reach maturity.

We'll start by recollecting all the resulting bond prices and putting them in a table:

| Years left to maturity| Price of bond X| Price of bond Y| 
|--|--|--| 
| 13 | \$1,126.6775 | \$883.32851| 
| 12 | $1,120.43775 | \$888.519 | 
| 10 | \$1,106.59302 | \$900.29225 | 
| 5 | \$1,062.37453 | \$939.91834 | 
| 1 |  \$1,014.2477 | \$985.90479 | 
| 0 | $1,000 | $1,000 | 

Now let's draw the graph. Let the horizontal axis represents times to maturity, and the vertical axis represents bond prices. The graph should look like this: 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/8e7b66ee-f0e6-41eb-8fc5-f485d618b58e-1653694381456447.png)

Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise.

First, we recalled how we could calculate the bond's price.

Then we calculated the bond prices for various periods until maturity. We have learned that the bond price will become closer to the face value with maturity. We illustrated this rule by drawing a graph in the last step.
